title: Tuesday, 26th June, 2018

Electric Dragon and what of the Sheinhardt Wig Company?

Baker Hughes is easy. $35bn or thereabouts.

BE11:15am

Otherwise .... hang on, there was a huge note a few weeks ago from JP Morgan on GE legacy .....

Timmmmmmmyyyyyy Hi there, could you please share any views or insights you have into Inmarsat/EchoStar? In particular, do you think ISAT is open to a deal? Or is the bid/ask too far apart? Would EchoStar go hostile? Thank you very much in advance!
FATDAZ Morning Healthcare biz has historically been flagged by US brokers as one to watch so will be interesting to see what happens with that
11:16 am
BE11:17am

............ that I can't find. So have Goldman instead.

BE11:17am

The bottom line in our view is that GE needs to shore up its balance sheet to mitigate the risk of a credit rating downgrade. As of the end of 2017, GE had ~$11bn in cash (excluding the $7bn from BHGE) on the parent balance sheet, but most of the cash is held permanently overseas. Therefore, GE typically needs to access

$16bn (4 quarter average) in commercial paper quarterly to meet its working capital needs. In the event GE’s debt were to be downgraded (Moody’s current long-term rating: A2; short-term rating: P-1), it would run the risk of being the largest commercial paper issuer in a less liquid short-term (P-2) market, with access to capital being constrained. While GE is undertaking several initiatives to improve its balance sheet, including building cash through asset sales and prioritizing internal cash generation, to avoid another dividend cut and potential rating downgrade we think the most prudent action would be for GE to consider suspending its common dividend for the next 18 months.

Groundhog Day Yes please - any news on ISAT that you can share? Thanks a lot

Note, importantly, the divi's being maintained.

Bluesky21 @ Electric Dragon - a 30 Rock reference! Dont’ get many of those any more ...

Okay, so Inmarsat then.

kalkaar Morning All, what do you guys make of the Eutelsat confirmation of interest in ISAT and then withdrawal of interest this morning? Thanks

It's worth retracing events here.

BE11:22am

Bloomberg had the story up that Eutelsat was weighing up an offer .....

Tom Dalgleish GE successfully jumped the shark since Edison founded it
11:23 am
BE11:23am

............ at just after 2pm yesterday, and it was one of those stories that we went, "well, duh. Of course it is. But there are lots and lots of reasons why Eutelsat probably won't be ......"

BE11:24am

Then the Bloomberg Internal Analysis Team began their thing.

BE11:24am

Eutelsat Should Consider Making an Offer for Inmarsat: BI React

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Eutelsat More Plausible Inmarsat Bidder Than Echostar: BI React

BE11:24am

Um ... yeah, kinda.

BE11:25am

The idea here is Eutelsat is too reliant on video so could do with Inmarsat's actual business, the marine and the aerospace stuff.

cheeckychappy funny stuff re Bloomborg Brycey
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Unlike Echostar, which really only cares about the spectrum licences, most likely.

BE11:25am

However, Eutelsat is already levered out of sight. 2.9x or so.

BE11:26am

So any bid for Inmarsat would require a huge rights issue.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Which a lot of shareholders don't seem wildly keen about, judging by yesterday's share price action.

cheeckychappy Also does anybody else find it curious how Bloomborg were yesterday moralising over whether its right hedge funds pay for exclusive private polling data while the very foundation of the company is about selling exclusive content to, er, hedge funds, traders, banks and fund managers...
BE11:27am

So ...... the story having been made public, and Eutelsat management having probably had a few sharp conversations with investors yesterday evening, it's all over already.

FATDAZ @chekychappy felt the whole tone of that piece was misplaced to say the least
BE11:28am

Does this change anything with the Echostar bid? No, not really. Eutelsat was always seen as an outside chance as a counterbidder given its debt.

BornCynic Morning - looks like ML is wilting in the heat - is it me or are you slowing up BE?
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Will Echostar pay up? We've no idea.

BE11:30am

Though you'd note that Echostar buying 10% of the convertible gives them a certain amount of downside protection in case of a counterbidder. So, eyes towards Viasat probably.

Tom Dalgleish Is ML the oubliette for journos?
BE11:31am

The comment I have has been bypassed by events. Have it anyway. Here's Exane.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Inmarsat’s exposure to the Mobility segment, the defensive move of keeping Echostar out of Europe, as well as the potential opex synergies (assumed at USD70m) and the hard to quantify capex synergies look like the main strategic benefits for this deal. However, Inmarsat offers no strategic benefits to Eutelsat’s core Video and Consumer Broadband strategy (80%+ of group EBITDA), nor would it efficiently reduce market overcapacity. Eutelsat does not appear to have a need for L-band GEO spectrum rights neither. In our view, acquiring Inmarsat would raise question marks on Eutelsat’s ability to deliver on its return to growth strategy through Video and Consumer Broadband.

cheeckychappy good use of the word oubliette Tom - just had to google it find out what it meant!
BE11:31am

While the timing and strategic rationale look questionable, we would also see limited financial appeal to this transaction, assuming a premium to the current spot price. Offering only a 10% premium would imply a 2019e EV/EBITDA multiple of c10x (vs. Eutelsat’s 7x), jeopardize the dividend policy (with a proforma 5.4x net debt to EBITDA) or require EUR2bn+ of capital increase.

BE11:32am

Over the last two years, Eutelsat’s retrenching strategy has helped protect FCF and dividend. This has resulted in its shares outperforming most of its global peers. Bar much higher opex and capex synergies than expected, we believe such a deal would make little sense. We think management is just tyre-kicking and unlikely to move. But we expect short term pressure on Eutelsat’s shares. Inflating its main competitor’s balance sheet (Echostar’s) by bidding up on its target…that would be a canny strategy.

Tom Dalgleish ...been slow since the youknowwhat tournament started
Tom Dalgleish ChCh, Vous oubliez?
